utterance: With me.
speaker: Higgles

utterance: Lord love you ; he trots round with me nights  like as if he was a man.
speaker: Higgles

utterance: You, boys, will have to camp out here by the  fire as well as you can, for thar ain't  but the one room.
speaker: Higgles

utterance: If it 's all the same  to you, boys, as we 're rather crowded, I '11 stop  here to-night
speaker: Higgles

utterance: Is there any of you that knows me ?
speaker: Higgles

utterance: Think again ! I lived at Marysville in '53. Everybody knew me there, and everybody had the  right to know me. I kept the Polka Saloon until  I came to live with Jim. That 's six years ago. Perhaps I've changed some.
speaker: Higgles

utterance: Well, you see I thought some of you must  have known me. There 's no great harm done,  anyway. What I was going to say was this : Jim  here   used to know me, if you did n't, and  spent a heap of money upon me. I reckon he  spent all he had. And one day it 's six years  ago this winter Jim came into my back room,  sat down on my sofy, like as you see him in that  chair, and never moved again without help. He  was struck all of a heap, and never seemed to  know what ailed him. The doctors came and said  as how it was caused all along of his way of life,  for Jim was mighty free and wild like, and  that he would never get better, and could n't last long anyway. They advised me to send him to  Frisco to the hospital, for he was no good to any  one and would be a baby all his life. . Perhaps it  was something in Jim's eye, perhaps it was that I  never had a baby, but I said ' No.' I was rich  then, for I was popular with everybody, gentle men like yourself, sir, came to see me, and I  sold out my business and bought this yer place,  because it was sort of out of the way of travel, you  see, and I brought my baby here.
speaker: Higgles

utterance: It was a long time before I could get the hang  of things about yer, for I was used to company  and excitement. I could n't get any woman to  help me, and a man I dursent trust ; but what  with the Indians hereabout, who 'd do odd jobs for  me, and having everything sent from the North  Fork, Jim and I managed to worry through. The  Doctor would run up from Sacramento once in a
speaker: Higgles

utterance: Miggles's baby/ as he  called Jim, and when he 'd go away, he 'd say,  ' Higgles ; you 're a trump, God bless you ' ; and  it did n't seem so lonely after that. But the last  time he was here he said, as he opened the door to  go, ' Do you know, Higgles, your baby will grow  up to be a man yet and an honor to his mother ;  but not here, Higgles, not here ! ' And I thought  he went away sad, and and
speaker: Higgles

utterance: The folks about here are very kind, The men from the fork used to hang  around here, until they found they was n't wanted,  and the women are kind, and don't call. I was  pretty lonely until I picked up Joaquiri in the  woods yonder one day, when he was n't so high,  and taught him to beg for his dinner ; and then  thai 's Polly that 's the magpie she knows no  end of tricks, and makes it quite sociable of even ings with her talk, and so I don't feel like as I  was the only livfng being about the ranch. And  Jim here, Jim  why, boys, you would admire to see how much he  knows for a man like him. Sometimes I bring  him flowers, and he looks at 'em just as natural as  if he knew 'em ; and times, when we 're sitting
speaker: Higgles

utterance: Why,  Lord ! I Ve  read him that whole side of the house this winter. There never was such a man for reading as Jim.
speaker: Higgles

speaker: Higgles

utterance: I was passin' by, and I thought I 'd just step in and see how things  was gittin' on with Tennessee thar, my pardner. It 's a hot night. I disremember any sich weather  before on the Bar.
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: Have you anything to say in behalf of the  prisoner ?
speaker: the Judge

utterance: Thet 's it, I come yar as Tennessee's pardner,  knowing him nigh on four year, off and on, wet  and dry, in luck and out o' luck. His ways ain't  allers my. ways, but thar ain't any p'ints in that  young man, thar ain't any liveliness as he 's been up . to, as I don't know. And you sez to rue, sez you,  confidential-like, and between man and man, sez  you, ' Do you know anything in his behalf ? ' and I
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: What should a man know of his  pardner ?
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: Is this all you have to say ?
speaker: the Judge

utterance: It ain't for me to say anything agin' him. And  now, what 's the case ? Here 's Tennessee wants  money, wants it bad, and does n't like to ask it of  his old pardner. Well, what does Tennessee do ? He lays for a stranger, and he fetches that stranger. And you lays for him, and you fetches him ; and  the honors is easy. And I put it to you, bein' a  far-minded man, and to you, gentlemen, all, as  far-minded men, ef this is n't so.
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: Prisoner, have  you .any questions to ask this man ?
speaker: the Judge

utterance: No ! no ! I play this yer hand alone. To come  down to the bed-rock, it 's just this : Tennessee,  thar, has played it pretty rough and expensive like on a stranger, and on this yer camp. And  now, what 's the fair thing ? Some would say  more ; some would say less. Here 's seventeen  hundred dollars in coarse gold and a watch, it 's  about all my pile, and call it square !
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: This yer is a lone hand, played alone,  and without my pardner
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: When a man," began Tennessee's Partner, slowly, " has been running free all day, what 's the natural thing for him to do ? Why, to come home. And if he ain't in a condition to go home, what can his best friend do ? Why, bring him home ! And here 's Tennessee has been running free, and we brings him home from his wander ing.
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: It ain't the first time that I Ve packed him on my back, as you see'd me now. It ain't the first time that I brought him to this yer cabin when he could n't help himself ; it ain't the first time that I and ' Jinny ' have waited for him on yon hill, and picked him up and so fetched him home, when he could n't speak, and did n't know me. And now that it 's the last time, why you see it 's sort of rough on his pardner.
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: And now, gentlemen, the fun'l 's over ; and my thanks, and Tennessee's thanks, to you for your trouble.
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: It is time to go for Tennessee ; I must put ' Jinny ' in the cart
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: There, now, steady, 'Jinny,' steady, old girl. How dark it is ! Look out for the ruts, and look out for him, too, old gal. Sometimes, you know, when he 's blind drunk, he drops down right in the trail. Keep on straight up to the pine on the top of the hill. Thar I told you so ! thar he is, coming this way, too, all by himself, sober, and his face a-shining. Tennessee ! Pardner !
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: I think I find the intoxicated portion of this community the least objectionable. I refer, my dear, to the men, of course. I do not know anything that could make the women tolerable.
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: looking in the winder.
speaker: Master Johnny Stidger

utterance: If you carried more of that for your self, you 'd do better.
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: I heerd tell that you were goin' down to the Bay to-morrow, and I could n't let you go until I came to thank you for your kindness to my Tommy.
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: Thank you, miss ; thank ye ! I thank you, miss, for that ! and if I am his mother, there ain't a sweeter, dearer, better boy lives than him. And if I ain't much as says it, thar ain't a sweeter, dearer, angeler teacher lives than he 's got.
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: It ain't for you to be complimented by the like of me, I know. It ain't for me to be comin' here, in broad day, to do it, either ; but I come to ask a favor, not for me, miss, not for me, but for the darling boy.
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: You see, miss, there 's no one the boy has any claim on but me, and I ain't the proper person to bring him up. I thought some, last year, of send ing him away to 'Frisco to school, but when they talked of bringing a schoolma'am here, I waited .till I saw you, and then I knew it was all right, and I could keep my boy a little longer. And 0, miss, he loves you so much ; and if you could hear him talk about you, in his pretty way, and if he could ask you what I ask you now, you could n't refuse him.
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: It is natural, it 's natural that he should take to you, miss, for his father, when I first knew him, was a gentleman, and the boy must forget me, sooner or later, and so I ain't a goin' to cry about that. For I come to ask you to take my Tommy, God bless him for the bestest, sweetest boy that lives, to to take him with you.
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: I 've money plenty, and it 's all yours and his. Put him in some good school, where you can go and see him, and help him to to to forget his mother. Do with him what you like. The worst you can do will be kindness to what he will learn with me. Only take him out of this wicked life, this cruel place, this home of shame and sor row. You will; I know you will, won't you? You will, you must not, you cannot say no ! You will make him as pure, as gentle as yourself; and when he has grown up, you will tell him his father's name, the name that has n't passed my lips for years, the name of Alexander Morton, whom they call here Sandy ! Miss Mary ! do not take your hand away ! Miss Mary, speak to me ! You will take my boy ? Do not put your face from me. I know it ought not to look on such as me. Miss Mary ! my God, be merciful ! she is leaving me !
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: I know it takes time to consider. I will wait here all night ; but I cannot go until you speak. Do not deny me now. You will ! I see it in your sweet face, such a face as I have seen in my dreams. I see it in your eyes, Miss Mary ! you will take my boy !
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: I will take the boy. Send him to .me to night.
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: Does this man know of your intention ?
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: No, nor cares. He has never even seen the child to know it.
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: Go to him at once, to-night, now ! Tell him what you have done. Tell him I have taken his child, and tell him he must never see see the child again. Wherever it may be, he must not come ; wherever I may take it, he must not follow ! There, go now, please, I 'm weary, and have much yet to do !
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: Good night.

utterance: You see, stranger gold is sure to come out 'er that theer claim but the old pro-pri-e-tor warn't of much account He was green, and let the boys about here jump him
speaker: our intelligent informant

utterance: His name war Fagg.
speaker: our intelligent informant

utterance: I 'm going home !
speaker: David Fagg

utterance: Going home ?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Yes, that is, I think I '11 take a trip to the Atlantic States. I came to see you, as you know I have some little property, and I have executed a power of attorney for you to manage my affairs. I have some papers I 'd like to leave with you. Will you take charge of them ?
speaker: David Fagg

utterance: Yes, But what of Nellie ?
speaker: narrator

utterance: I shall not marry Nellie, that is, I think that I had better not.
speaker: David Fagg

utterance: David Fagg, you 're of no account !
speaker: narrator

utterance: Yes, that 's it ! I 'm-of no account ! But I always knew it. You see I thought Rattler loved that girl as well as I did, and I knew she liked him better than she did me, and would be happier I dare say with him. But then I knew that old Robins would have preferred me to him, as I was better off, and the girl would do as he said, and, you see, I thought I was kinder in the way, and so I left. But, for fear the old man might object to Rattler, I 've lent him enough to set him up in business for himself in Dogtown. A pushing, active, brilliant fellow, you know, like Rattler can get along, and will soon be in his old position again, and you need n't be hard on him, you know, if he does n't. Good by.
speaker: David Fagg

utterance: What can she want here ?
speaker: the Master

utterance: I come here to-night, because I knew you was alone. I would n't come here when them gals was here. I hate 'em and they hates me. That 's why. You keep school, don't you ? I want to be teached !
speaker: Melissa Smith

utterance: My name 's Mliss, Mliss Smith ! You can bet your life on that. My father 's Old Smith, Old Bummer Smith, that 's what 's the matter with him. Mliss Smith, and I 'm coming to school !
speaker: Melissa Smith

utterance: Well ?
speaker: the Master

utterance: she 'd be good, she did n't mean to
speaker: Melissa Smith

utterance: Why had she left the Sabbath school ? why ? yes. What did he (McSnagley) want to tell her she was wicked for ? What did he tell her that God hated her for ? If God hated her, what did she want to go to Sabbath school for ? She did n't want to be " benolden " to anybody who hated her.
speaker: Melissa Smith

utterance: Had she told McSnagley this ?
speaker: the Master

utterance: Yes, she had.
speaker: Melissa Smith

utterance: Her father? What father? Whose father? What had he ever done for her ? Why did the girls hate her ? Come now ! what made the folks say, " Old Bummer Smith's Mliss ! " when she passed ? Yes ; yes. She wished he was dead, she was dead, everybody was dead
speaker: Melissa Smith

utterance: good night.
speaker: the Master

utterance: Are you busy ? Can you come with me ?
speaker: Melissa Smith

utterance: Come, then, quick !
speaker: Melissa Smith

utterance: To see my father.
speaker: Melissa Smith

utterance: RESPECTED SIR, When you read this, I am run  away. Never to come back. Never, NEVER, NEVER. You can give my beeds to Mary Jennings, and my  Amerika's Pride [a highly colored lithograph from a  tobacco-box] to Sally Flanders. But don't you give  anything to Clytie Morpher. Don't you dare to. Do  you know what my oppinion is of her, it is this, she is  perfekly disgustin. That is all and no more at pres ent from Yours respectfully, MELISSA SMITH.
speaker: MELISSA SMITH

utterance: What do you want ?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: I want some crab-apples.
speaker: the master

utterance: Sha' n't have 'em ! go away. Why don't you  get 'em of Clytemnerestera ? you wicked thing !
speaker: Mliss

utterance: I am hungry, Lissy. I have eaten nothing  since dinner yesterday. I am famished !
speaker: the master

utterance: Dig under the tree near the roots, and you '11  find lots ; but mind you don't tell,
speaker: Melissa

utterance: If I come down and give you some, you'll  promise you won't touch me ?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Hope you '11 die if you do !
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Do you feel better ?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Lissy, do you remember the first  evening you came to see me ?
speaker: the master

utterance: You asked me if you might come to school,  for you wanted to learn something and be better,  and I said
speaker: the master

utterance: Come.
speaker: the child

utterance: What would you say if the master now came  to you and said that he was lonely without his little  scholar, and that he wanted her to come and teach  him to be better ?
speaker: the master

utterance: We are waiting, Lissy
speaker: the master

utterance: You ain't mad ?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: No.
speaker: the master

utterance: Nor bothered ?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: No.
speaker: the master

utterance: Nor  hungry?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: No.
speaker: the master

utterance: Nor thinking of her?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Of whom, Lissy?
speaker: the master

utterance: That white girl.
speaker: Mliss

utterance: No.
speaker: the master

utterance: Upon your  word ?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Yes.
speaker: the master

utterance: And sacred  honor ?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Yes.
speaker: the master

utterance: Meelissy ! ye were speaking of the revolutions  of this yere yearth and the move-merits of the sun,  and I think ye said it had been a doing of it since  the creashun, eh ?
speaker: McSnagley

utterance: Yes
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Well, war that the truth ?
speaker: McSnagley

utterance: Yes
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Stick to it, Mliss !
speaker: the biggest scamp in the diggings

utterance: Joshua commanded the sun to stand still, and  it obeyed him !
speaker: Clytie

utterance: It 's a d n lie. I don't believe it !
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Now take me home !
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Why ?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Please, sir ?
speaker: Aristides Morpher

utterance: Well, my little man, what is it ? quick !
speaker: the master

utterance: Please, sir, me and ' Kerg ' thinks that Mliss  is going to run away agin.
speaker: Aristides Morpher

utterance: What 's that, sir ?
speaker: the master

utterance: Why, sir, she don't stay home any more, and  ' Kerg ' and me see her talking with one of those  actor fellers, and she 's with him now ; and please,  sir, yesterday she told 'Kerg' and me she could  make a speech as well as Miss Cellerstina Mont moressy, and she spouted right off by heart,
speaker: Aristides

utterance: What actor ?
speaker: the master

utterance: Him as wears the shiny hat. And hair. And  gold pin. And gold chain
speaker: Aristides

utterance: Where were they talking ?
speaker: the master

utterance: At the Arcade
speaker: Aristides

utterance: Eun down home
speaker: the master

utterance: If Mliss is there, come to the Arcade and tell me. If she is n't there, stay home ; run !
speaker: the master

utterance: S'pose she has ?
speaker: the man with the glazed hat

utterance: If you are a gentleman, I have only to tell you  that I am her guardian, and responsible for her ca reer. You know as well as I do the kind of life  you offer her. As you may learn of any one here,  I have already brought her out of an existence  worse than death, out of the streets and the con tamination of vice. I am trying to do so again. Let us talk like men. She has neither father,  mother, sister, or brother. Are you seeking to give  her an equivalent for these ?
speaker: the master
addressee: the man with the glazed hat

utterance: I know that she is a strange, wilful girl, but she is better than she was. I believe that I have some influence over her still. I beg and hope, therefore, that you will take no  further steps in this matter, but as a man, as a gen tleman, leave her to me. I am willing
speaker: the master
addressee: the man with the glazed hat

utterance: Want her yourself, do you ? That cock won't  fight here, young man !
speaker: the man with the glazed hat

utterance: It 's all right, my boy. She 's  home !
speaker: Mr. Morpher

utterance: Did you kill him ?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: No I
speaker: the Master

utterance: That 's what I gave you the knife for !
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Gave me the knife ?
speaker: the Master

utterance: Yes, gave you the knife. I was there under the bar. Saw you hit him. Saw you both fall. He dropped his old knife. I gave it to you. Why did n't you stick him ?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Yes. If you'd asked me, I'd told you I was off with the play-actors. Why was I off with the play-actors ? Because you wouldn't tell me you was going away. I knew it. I heard you tell the Doctor so. I was n't a goin' to stay here alone with those Morphers. I 'd rather die first.
speaker: Mliss

utterance: That 's the poison plant you said would kill me. I '11 go with the play-actors, or I '11 eat this and die here. I don't care which. I won't stay here, where they hate and despise me ! Neither would you let me, if you did n't hate and despise me too 1
speaker: Mliss

utterance: If you lock me up in jail, to keep me from the play-actors, I '11 poison myself. Father killed himself, why shouldn't I ? You said a mouthful of that root would kill me, and I always carry it here,
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Lissy, will you go with me 1
speaker: the Master

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Mliss

utterance: But now to-night ?
speaker: the Master

utterance: To-night.
speaker: Mliss

utterance: ' Abimelech took her from Abraham ' ah, little one, excellent ! ' Jacob sent to see his brother ' - - body of Christ ! that up-stroke of thine, Paquita, is marvellous ; the Governor shall see it !
speaker: the Commander

utterance: Tor yourself, Sefior Captain, accept my hospitality. The fort is yours as long as you shall grace it with your distinguished presence
speaker: the Commander

utterance: Now, then, which on ye '11 see the stranger up the creek to Altascar's, to-morrow ?
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: Kin you go, Kerg ?
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: Who 's to look up stock in Strarberry per ar-ie?
speaker: Kerg

utterance: Well, Tom, wot 's to hinder you from goin' ?
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: Mam 's goin' to Brown's store at sun-up, and I s'pose I Ve got to pack her and the baby agin.
speaker: Tom

utterance: Wise ?
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: I told ye to get Brown to give you a pair the last time you war down the jiver.
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: Said he would n't without'en order. Said it was like pulling gum-teeth to get the money from you even then.
speaker: Wise

utterance: Well, Joe, ef your boots are new, and you are n't pestered with wimmin and children, p'r'aps you'll go,
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: Got no saddle.
speaker: Kanaka Joe

utterance: Wot 's gone of your saddle ?
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: Kerg, there,
speaker: Kanaka Joe

utterance: You lie !
speaker: Kerg

utterance: Theer 's George comin' ! why don't ye ask him ? He '11 go and introduce you to Don Fernandy's darter, too, ef you ain't pertickler.
speaker: Wise

utterance: Ah, littlest of all,sweet one, what doest thou here ? Art thou not afraid of him whom every one shuns and fears ?
speaker: the Commander

utterance: No, not in the dark. I hear your voice, the old voice ; I feel your touch, the old touch ; but I see not your eye, Senor Comandante. That only I fear, and that, Senor, my father, that I know is not thine own !
speaker: Paquita

utterance: Look at 'em holdin' the finest grazin' land that ever lay outer doors ? Whar 's the papers for it ? Was it grants ? Mighty fine grants, most of 'em made arter the 'Merrikans got possession. More fools the 'Merrikans for lettin' 'em hold 'em. Wat paid for 'em ? 'Merrikan blood and money.
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: Did n't they oughter have suthin out of their native country ? Wot for ? Did they ever im prove ? Got a lot of yaller-skinned diggers, not so sensible as niggers to look arter stock, and they a sittin' home and smokin'. With their gold and silver candlesticks, and missions, and crucifixens, priests and graven idols, and sich ? Them sort things wurent allowed in Mizzoori.
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: It was agin Nater, and agin God. God never intended gold in the rocks to be made into heathen candlesticks and crucifixens. That 's why he sent 'Merrikins here. Nater never intended such a climate for lazy lopers. She never gin six months' sunshine to be slept and smoked away.
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: You'd better sleep there to-night; you '11 be more comfortable, and I '11 call you early.
speaker: George

utterance: Ours!
speaker: George

utterance: About how many, George ?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Don't know.
speaker: George

utterance: How many ?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Well, p'r'aps three thousand head. We don't know, takes five men to look 'em up and keep run.
speaker: George

utterance: What are they worth ?
speaker: narrator

utterance: About thirty dollars a head.
speaker: George

utterance: I Ve tried to get the old man to sell and build, but you know he says it ain't no use to settle down, just yet. We must keep movin'. In fact, he built the shanty for that purpose, lest titles should fall through, and we 'd have to get up and move stakes further down.
speaker: George

utterance: Toro !
speaker: George

utterance: That 's not our brand; they 're strange stock.
speaker: George

utterance: Toro
speaker: George

utterance: Never horsemen, sometimes footmen. Not through rage, you know, but curiosity. They think a man and his horse are one, and if they meet a chap afoot, they run him down and trample him under hoof, in the pursuit of knowledge. But here 's the lower bench of the foot hills, and here 's Altascar's corral, and that white building you see yonder is the casa.
speaker: George

utterance: Que lueno ? 7 Your courts are always just.
speaker: Senor Altascar

utterance: The deputies will be here to-morrow to run the lines from this initial point, and there will be no further trouble, I believe, gentlemen.
speaker: narrator

utterance: And I, Fernando Jesus Maria Altascar, put you in possession of my land in the fashion of my country.
speaker: Fernando Jesus Maria Altascar

utterance: Take the llano ! and take this with it. May the drought seize your cattle till their tongues hang down as long as those of your lying lawyers ! May it be the curse and torment of your old age, as you and yours have made it of mine !
speaker: Fernando Jesus Maria Altascar

utterance: Let him curse on. He '11 find 'em coming home to him sooner than -the cattle he has lost through his sloth and pride. The Lord is on the side of the just, as well as agin all slanderers and re vilers.
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: Stealer of the Sacrament ! Open not ! open not, I say, your lying, Judas lips to me ! Ah ! half-breed, with the soul of a cayote ! Car-r-r ramba !
speaker: Fernando Jesus Maria Altascar

utterance: Will you go back with us to-night ?
speaker: George

utterance: Well then, good by.
speaker: George

utterance: Good by, George.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Light ahead.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Stern, all ; a steamer !
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Hold hard there ! Steamer be d d ! It 's a house, and a big one too.
speaker: the coxswain

utterance: There 's some one in it, by Heavens ! Give way, boys, lay her alongside. Handsomely, now ! The door 's fastened ; try the window ; no ! here 's another !
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Joseph Tryan !
speaker: narrator

utterance: Look up, old man, look up ! Your wife and children, where are they ? The boys, George ! Are they here ? are they safe ?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Joseph Tryan, don't you know me ? the sur veyor who surveyed your ranch, the Espiritu Santo ? Look up, old man !
speaker: narrator

utterance: Hush!
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: Listen !
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: I 'm a moving off !
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: Moving off ?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Hush ! Don't speak so loud. Moving off. Ah ! wot 's that ? Don't you hear ? there ! lis ten !
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: It 's them wot he sent ! Old Altascar sent. They 've been here all night. I heard 'em first in the creek, when they came to tell the old man to move farther off. They came nearer and nearer. They whispered under the door, and I saw their eyes on the step, their cruel, hard eyes. Ah, why don't they quit ?
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: Why don't they quit, then ? They have the stock, all gone gone, gone for the hides and hoofs.
speaker: Joseph Tryan

utterance: There are other boats below us. The shanty cannot have drifted far, and perhaps the family are safe by this time.
speaker: the coxswain

utterance: Is it George Tryan ?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Don't know ; but he 's a sweet one, whoever he is. You '11 find him for'ard.
speaker: the engineer

utterance: These are high old times, ain't they ? I say, what do you reckon 's become* o' them thar bound'ry moniments you stuck ? Ah !
speaker: Wise

utterance: So you 've picked up the ole man in the shanty, clean crazy ? He must have been soft to have stuck there instead o' leavin' with the old woman. Did n't know me from Adam ; took me for George !
speaker: Wise

utterance: Don't know whar he is ! If he 'd tended stock instead of running about the prairie, packin' off wimmin and children, he might have saved suthin. He lost every hoof and hide, I '11 bet a cookey ! Say you, when are you goin' to give us some grub ? I 'm hungry 'nough to skin and eat a hoss. Eeckon I '11 turn butcher when things is dried up, and save hides, horns, and taller.
speaker: Wise

utterance: Have you any idea what you '11 do, Wise ?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Thar ain't much to do now. I '11 have to lay over a spell, I reckon, till things comes, straight. The land ain't worth much now, and won't be, I dessay, for some time. Wonder whar the ole man '11 drive stakes next.
speaker: Wise

utterance: I meant as to your father and George, Wise.
speaker: narrator

utterance: 0, the ole man and I '11 go on to ' Miles's, ' whar Tom packed the old woman and babies last week. George '11 turn up somewhar atween this and Altascar's, ef he ain't thar now.
speaker: Wise

utterance: I ask how the Altascars have suffered.
speaker: narrator

utterance: Well, I reckon he ain't lost much in stock. I should n't wonder if George helped him drive 'em up the foot-hills. And his ' casa ' 's built too high. 0, thar ain't any water thar, you bet. Ah/, says Wise, with reflective 'admiration, "those greasers ain't the darned fools people thinks 'em. I '11 bet thar ain't one swamped out in all'er Californy."
speaker: Wise

utterance: I shall keep on a little farther, and try to find George.
speaker: narrator

utterance: I don't think you '11 save much. What 's the percentage, workin' on shares, eh !
speaker: Wise

utterance: Poco a poco Seiior, not now. You are tired,  you have hunger, you have cold. Necessary it is  you should have peace.
speaker: Senor Altascar

utterance: You have eat?
speaker: Senor Altascar

utterance: Yes
speaker: narrator

utterance: Bueno, eat when you can, food and appetite  are not always.
speaker: Senor Altascar

utterance: It was made by me, Seiior.
speaker: Senor Altascar

utterance: I kept it as a clew to him, Don Altascar. If I could find him
speaker: narrator

utterance: He is here.
speaker: Senor Altascar

utterance: Here ! and
speaker: narrator

utterance: He was honest and brave/
speaker: Senor Altascar
